Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site is to give students experience with fundamental research in acquisition and fusion of multisource sensing data related to human beings. Students will be challenged to make sense of human behaviors and cognitive processes with hardware, software, and complex thinking, exploring the nexus of computational science, scientific practice, and the human experience. Traditionally, sensors have been understood narrowly, often as physiological measurements. This project envisions sensing in broader, new ways, as time-evolving measurable data directly linked to individuals and, by extension, to their communities. With this understanding, sensing data may involve language, social network and environment signals, or emotional-creative reactions. This REU site will: (1) advance fundamental research in computational sensing; (2) expose students to a research environment that innovatively blends computer and information science and computational liberal arts, infused with career-enhancing learning elements, and (3) ensure that transformative research experiences reach an unusually diverse student group of underrepresented subpopulations in computer science.

The projects link in applications that students can directly relate to and that enable them to make concrete, real-world contributions. Further, the increasing demand for collaborative team science requires a new generation of scientists who approach research questions differently, exploring complementary perspectives and integrating methodologies and analysis tools in creative ways. Fundamental research in multisource data acquisition and fusion has valuable implications for many fields including human-computer interaction, accessibility, health and well-being, and gaming. This REU program is designed to build essential life-long capabilities in students for continued research careers, and to yield positive outcomes at the institutional and research community levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU Site in Computational Sensing at Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) provided three diverse student cohorts with 10-week experiences with fundamental research in acquisition, analysis, and fusion of multisource sensing data related to human beings. Using a team science approach, each project engaged two students and two or more experienced faculty research mentors from different academic units. Less than a quarter of the students had prior exposure to transdisciplinary research. Remote pre-program and post-program activities further expanded the mentoring interactions. The Site also involved career-enhancing professional development programming.

Intellectual Merit: In total, 15 team-based projects engaged 30 REU students. Four additional students participated in the Site and completed three further research projects. Research in the REU Site developed new methods to collect, analyze, and visualize multimodal data from humans including software and algorithms. Students presented work in progress in lightning and achievement talks and learned how to prepare technical research reports. At the end, all students presented a poster or a talk at the RIT Undergraduate Research Symposium. The Site produced 15 papers submitted for peer review; 13 have been published, one is accepted, and one is under review. These publications involved 25 students as primary authors, and over a dozen REU students presented research findings at technical research conferences or workshops. Three students also presented at the REU Symposium of the Council on Undergraduate Research. The Site produced materials for logistics, training, assessment, outreach, and communication. Work conducted led to three research grant proposals and the creation of the Human-centered Computational Sensing Workshop organized twice at the international PerCom conference (HCCS 2018 and HCCS 2020).

The research conducted in the REU Site advanced knowledge and contributed new methods and discoveries for how to collect and computationally process, analyze, and fuse multiple human sensing data streams, as well as findings with implications for future research in artificial intelligence, human-computer interaction, affective computing, and cognitive science. 

Example projects with outcomes:

  1. In 2016, a project developed a method for studying video-based online learning, linking human sensing data of learners collected while viewing the lecture video to their post-lecture quiz scores. In addition to the new method, the findings included that the difficulty level in learning materials impacted measurable physiological behavior, and the work increased understanding of multisource data capture.

  2. In 2017, an LSAMP student, who was an additional participant, captured and analyzed extracted face-based signals conveying affective reactions to content, with the goal of understanding their temporal data patterns as observers viewed video clips of distinct emotional character. Contributions included the extension of a method for estimating pulse from face video, a new visualization for linking self-reported emotional events via clickers to skin response peaks and facial expressions, and insights into affective reactions to content from physically noninvasive devices such as web cameras. 

  3. In 2018, a project explored head-mounted immersive technologies to prototype and capture internal and external state data from smart home devices, together with head orientation information. The work introduced an approach to conduct repeatable experimentation of smartspace technologies at a lower cost with direct user input to infer intent and train activity recognition models. Another project from this year developed a method to meaningfully fuse gaze and dialog data, co-collected from pairs of speakers.

The team projects maintained student interest by being grounded in real-world problems in society including in education, wellness, leisure, visual understanding, and data annotation.

Broader Impacts: The Site attracted about 450 applicants, with its largest applicant pool in the final year. After a two-stage selection process that focused on diverse cohorts, 30 participants represented over 25 institutions and included, on average, 60% students from institutions with limited research opportunities in computer science, 50% women, 30% URM, and 20% experiencing a disability. There were participants from other underrepresented groups. 

The REU Site aimed to support students in developing research identity. Many were later accepted into Master's and PhD programs in Computer Science or related fields at research universities. The program also offered career-enhancing training. This included workshops by faculty, a non-credit seminar on graduate school and research topics, a computational sensing journal club, a field trip to an industry research lab, and an REU Graduate Study and Research Symposium organized with other local REU programs. In a  panel, awardees of the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship spoke about their experiences. The REU Site introduced a Teaching-to-Mentoring Bridge talk series with faculty discussing research areas and their career paths.

Community outreach included exhibits at the Imagine RIT: Creativity and Innovation Festival, sensing equipment demonstrations at a public library, a women in STEM fair, and sharing with scientific communities about the REU Site and relevant research in nine talks and a roundtable. The REU Site activities and published and presented work have been communicated on a regularly updated website, as well as in media and outreach materials.
